messages.content: If I fork a repo on GitHub, can I keep merging the original repo into my fork?

Yes, if you fork a repository on GitHub, you can keep merging the original repository into your fork. This is because forking creates a copy of the original repository in your GitHub account, which you can modify and work on independently.

To keep your fork up-to-date with the original repository, you can follow these steps:

1. Clone your forked repository to your local machine.
2. Add the original repository as a remote to your forked repository using the following command:
```
git remote add upstream <original repository URL>
```
3. Fetch the changes from the original repository using the following command:
```
git fetch upstream
```
4. Merge the changes from the original repository into your forked repository using the following command:
```
git merge upstream/main
```
Note that in step 4, `main` refers to the name of the default branch of the repository. If the original repository uses a different default branch, replace `main` with the name of that branch.

After completing these steps, your forked repository should be up-to-date with the original repository.
